title: Ichthyology
description:
The branch of zoology dedicated to the study of fish.
Example: Fish science

title: Osteichthyes
description:
A class of bony fish characterized by a skeleton made of bone.
Example: Salmon

title: Chondrichthyes
description:
A class of cartilaginous fish including sharks, rays, and skates.
Example: Shark

title: Actinopterygii
description:
Ray-finned fish, the largest group of bony fish.
Example: Goldfish

title: Sarcopterygii
description:
Lobe-finned fish, including lungfish and coelacanths.
Example: Coelacanth

title: Elasmobranchii
description:
A subclass of cartilaginous fish including sharks and rays.
Example: Great white shark

title: Holocephali
description:
A subclass of cartilaginous fish including chimaeras.
Example: Chimaera

title: Teleostei
description:
A diverse group of advanced bony fish.
Example: Tuna

title: Cypriniformes
description:
An order including carps and minnows.
Example: Carp

title: Perciformes
description:
The largest order of fish, including perches and cichlids.
Example: Tilapia

title: Siluriformes
description:
An order including catfish, which have barbels.
Example: Catfish

title: Salmoniformes
description:
An order including salmon and trout.
Example: Trout

title: Clupeiformes
description:
An order including herrings and sardines.
Example: Herring

title: Anguilliformes
description:
An order including eels and morays.
Example: Eel

title: Scorpaeniformes
description:
An order including scorpionfish and lionfish.
Example: Lionfish

title: Gadiformes
description:
An order including cod and haddock.
Example: Cod

title: Lophiiformes
description:
An order including anglerfish.
Example: Anglerfish

title: Tetraodontiformes
description:
An order including pufferfish and boxfish.
Example: Pufferfish

title: Fish Morphology
description:
The study of external and internal structures of fish.
Example: Fish anatomy

title: Lateral Line System
description:
A sensory system detecting water movements and vibrations.
Example: Shark lateral line

title: Swim Bladder
description:
A gas-filled organ aiding in buoyancy control.
Example: Goldfish swim bladder

title: Operculum
description:
A bony plate covering and protecting the gills.
Example: Trout operculum

title: Gill Rakers
description:
Comb-like structures in gills filtering food particles.
Example: Whale shark gill rakers

title: Barbels
description:
Whisker-like sensory organs on some fish.
Example: Catfish barbels

title: Nares
description:
Fish nostrils used for detecting chemicals in water.
Example: Salmon nares

title: Fish Scales
description:
The protective outer covering of fish bodies.
Example: Fish scales

title: Ctenoid Scales
description:
Scales with tiny comb-like edges, found in perch.
Example: Bass scales

title: Cycloid Scales
description:
Scales with smooth edges, found in salmon.
Example: Salmon scales

title: Ganoid Scales
description:
Diamond-shaped hard scales found in garfish.
Example: Gar scales

title: Placoid Scales
description:
Tooth-like scales found in sharks.
Example: Shark scales

title: Countershading
description:
A coloration pattern with a dark top and light belly.
Example: Shark camouflage

title: Cryptic Coloration
description:
A coloration pattern helping fish blend with surroundings.
Example: Flounder

title: Mimicry in Fish
description:
Imitating other species for survival advantages.
Example: Cleaner wrasse

title: Bioluminescence
description:
The production of light by marine organisms.
Example: Deep-sea anglerfish

title: Electroreception
description:
The ability to sense electrical fields in water.
Example: Electric eel

title: Ampullae of Lorenzini
description:
Specialized electroreceptive organs in cartilaginous fish.
Example: Shark ampullae

title: Fish Vision
description:
The ability of fish to perceive colors and shapes.
Example: Betta fish vision

title: Tapetum Lucidum
description:
A reflective layer behind the retina enhancing vision.
Example: Shark eye

title: Fish Hearing
description:
The detection of sound vibrations in water.
Example: Carp hearing

title: Weberian Apparatus
description:
A set of bones aiding in hearing in some fish.
Example: Catfish Weberian apparatus

title: Otoliths
description:
Ear stones in fish used for balance and age determination.
Example: Fish ear stones

title: Fish Osmoregulation
description:
The process of regulating water and salt balance.
Example: Tilapia osmoregulation

title: Stenohaline Fish
description:
Fish that can tolerate only a narrow range of salinity.
Example: Goldfish

title: Euryhaline Fish
description:
Fish that can tolerate a wide range of salinity.
Example: Salmon

title: Anadromous Fish
description:
Fish that migrate from saltwater to freshwater to spawn.
Example: Eel

title: Catadromous Fish
description:
Fish that migrate from freshwater to saltwater to spawn.
Example: Barramundi

title: Diadromous Fish
description:
Fish that migrate between fresh and saltwater environments.
Example: Trout

title: Fish Schooling
description:
The coordinated movement of fish in groups.
Example: Herring school

title: Shoaling Behavior
description:
The behavior of fish aggregating for social reasons.
Example: Mackerel shoal

title: Territoriality in Fish
description:
The defense of an area by a fish against intruders.
Example: Betta fish

title: Fish Migration
description:
The seasonal movement of fish for spawning or feeding.
Example: Salmon migration

title: Pelagic Fish
description:
Fish that live in the open ocean, away from the bottom.
Example: Tuna

title: Demersal Fish
description:
Fish that live near the sea floor.
Example: Cod

title: Benthic Fish
description:
Fish that dwell at the bottom of water bodies.
Example: Flounder

title: Reef Fish
description:
Fish that inhabit coral reef ecosystems.
Example: Clownfish

title: Abyssal Fish
description:
Fish that live in the deepest parts of the ocean.
Example: Anglerfish

title: Epipelagic Zone
description:
The uppermost oceanic zone where sunlight penetrates.
Example: Shallow ocean

title: Mesopelagic Zone
description:
The twilight zone of the ocean with limited light.
Example: Twilight zone

title: Bathypelagic Zone
description:
A deep-sea zone where no sunlight reaches.
Example: Deep ocean

title: Abyssopelagic Zone
description:
A near-bottom zone in the deep ocean.
Example: Abyssal plains

title: Hadalpelagic Zone
description:
The deepest oceanic zone, beyond abyssal depths.
Example: Trench zone

title: Ram Ventilation
description:
A ventilation process where fish must swim to breathe.
Example: Sharks

title: Buccal Pumping
description:
A breathing method using mouth muscles to force water over gills.
Example: Goldfish

title: Obligate Ram Ventilators
description:
Fish that must continuously swim to respire.
Example: Tuna

title: Facultative Air Breather
description:
Fish that can switch between water and air breathing.
Example: Betta fish

title: Obligate Air Breather
description:
Fish that must breathe air to survive.
Example: Lungfish

title: Lungfish
description:
A type of fish with primitive lungs for air breathing.
Example: Australian lungfish

title: Labyrinth Organ
description:
An organ in some fish allowing aerial respiration.
Example: Gourami

title: Gill Filaments
description:
Thin structures in gills that extract oxygen from water.
Example: Salmon gills

title: Gill Arches
description:
Bony structures that support the gills.
Example: Fish skeleton

title: Gill Lamellae
description:
Microscopic structures on gill filaments enhancing gas exchange.
Example: Gill surface

title: Fish Respiration
description:
The process by which fish extract oxygen from water.
Example: Goldfish breathing

title: Countercurrent Exchange
description:
A mechanism enhancing oxygen uptake in gills.
Example: Trout oxygen exchange

title: Hyperosmotic Regulation
description:
The regulation of water balance in freshwater fish.
Example: Freshwater fish

title: Hypoosmotic Regulation
description:
The regulation of water balance in marine fish.
Example: Marine fish

title: Eurythermal Fish
description:
Fish that can tolerate a wide range of temperatures.
Example: Tilapia

title: Stenothermal Fish
description:
Fish that can only survive in a narrow temperature range.
Example: Icefish

title: Thermocline
description:
A layer where temperature changes rapidly with depth.
Example: Deep-sea fish

title: Upwelling
description:
The process of nutrient-rich water rising to the surface.
Example: Sardine migration

title: Fish Metabolism
description:
The biochemical processes sustaining fish life.
Example: Tuna energy

title: Poikilothermic
description:
Having a body temperature that fluctuates with surroundings.
Example: Catfish metabolism

title: Homeothermic Fish
description:
Fish maintaining a stable internal temperature.
Example: Moonfish

title: Regional Endothermy
description:
Maintaining higher internal temperatures in specific body regions.
Example: Shark muscles

title: Gigantothermy
description:
A phenomenon where large-bodied fish retain heat.
Example: Great white shark

title: Antifreeze Proteins
description:
Proteins preventing ice formation in polar fish.
Example: Icefish blood

title: Lateral Compression
description:
A body shape adapted for quick maneuvering in water.
Example: Angelfish

title: Dorso-Ventral Compression
description:
A flattened body shape suited for bottom dwelling.
Example: Skates

title: Fusiform Body Shape
description:
A streamlined body shape for fast swimming.
Example: Marlin

title: Depressed Body Shape
description:
A flattened body adapted for resting on the bottom.
Example: Stingray

title: Anguilliform Body Shape
description:
An elongated body shape used by eels.
Example: Eel

title: Sagittiform Body Shape
description:
A torpedo-like body shape suited for rapid swimming.
Example: Pike

title: Globiform Body Shape
description:
A rounded body shape found in slow-moving fish.
Example: Pufferfish

title: Ostraciiform Motion
description:
A tail-driven swimming motion seen in boxfish.
Example: Boxfish

title: Amiiform Motion
description:
A motion using undulations of the dorsal fin.
Example: Knifefish

title: Labriform Motion
description:
A motion relying on pectoral fin movements.
Example: Wrasse

title: Rajiform Motion
description:
A motion where fish swim by undulating their bodies.
Example: Ray

title: Carangiform Motion
description:
A motion involving side-to-side tail beats.
Example: Mackerel

title: Thunniform Motion
description:
A motion used by tunas for fast swimming.
Example: Tuna

title: Oviparous Fish
description:
Fish that lay eggs which develop externally.
Example: Salmon eggs

title: Ovoviviparous Fish
description:
Fish that retain eggs inside the body until hatching.
Example: Guppy

title: Viviparous Fish
description:
Fish that give birth to live young.
Example: Shark birth

title: Fish Reproductive Strategies
description:
Different methods fish use for reproduction.
Example: Fish reproduction

title: Broadcast Spawning
description:
A reproductive method where fish release eggs and sperm into water.
Example: Cod spawning

title: Mouthbrooding
description:
A method where fish protect and carry eggs in their mouths.
Example: Cichlid

title: Nest Building
description:
Fish build structures to protect their eggs.
Example: Stickleback

title: Parental Care
description:
Any effort by fish to protect and raise offspring.
Example: Seahorse

title: Hermaphroditic Fish
description:
Fish that have both male and female reproductive organs.
Example: Clownfish

title: Sequential Hermaphroditism
description:
Changing sex during different life stages.
Example: Grouper

title: Protandry
description:
Fish that start as males and later become females.
Example: Anemonefish

title: Protogyny
description:
Fish that start as females and later become males.
Example: Wrasse

title: Gynogenesis
description:
A form of asexual reproduction requiring sperm but not genes from males.
Example: Amazon molly

title: Hybridogenesis
description:
A reproductive process where hybrids reproduce clonally.
Example: Hybrid fish

title: Unisexual Fish
description:
Fish that reproduce without males.
Example: Poecilia formosa

title: Parthenogenesis
description:
Asexual reproduction where embryos develop without fertilization.
Example: Whiptail lizard

title: Fish Growth
description:
The process of fish increasing in size.
Example: Trout growth

title: Indeterminate Growth
description:
A growth pattern where fish continue to grow throughout life.
Example: Carp

title: Fish Longevity
description:
The lifespan of fish species.
Example: Shark lifespan

title: Age Determination in Fish
description:
Methods used to determine the age of fish.
Example: Otolith rings

title: Fish Larvae
description:
The early stage of fish development.
Example: Tuna larvae

title: Fry
description:
Young fish that have recently hatched.
Example: Goldfish fry

title: Juvenile Fish
description:
A transitional stage between fry and adulthood.
Example: Bass juvenile

title: Metamorphosis in Fish
description:
Transformation from larval to adult fish form.
Example: Flatfish

title: Fish Eggs
description:
Reproductive cells of fish.
Example: Salmon eggs

title: Fish Hatchery
description:
Facilities for artificial breeding of fish.
Example: Hatchery salmon

title: Aquaculture
description:
The cultivation of fish for food.
Example: Tilapia

title: Fish Farming
description:
The commercial breeding and harvesting of fish.
Example: Catfish farming

title: Mariculture
description:
The farming of fish in marine environments.
Example: Shrimp farming

title: Ornamental Fish Trade
description:
The trade of decorative fish for aquariums.
Example: Guppies

title: Fish Stock Assessment
description:
Analyzing fish populations for conservation.
Example: Cod population

title: Fishery Management
description:
The regulation of fish populations for sustainability.
Example: Lobster fishery

title: Overfishing
description:
Excessive fishing reducing fish populations.
Example: Tuna depletion

title: Bycatch
description:
Unintended marine species caught during fishing.
Example: Shark finning

title: Sustainable Fishing
description:
Harvesting fish in a way that ensures future stocks.
Example: MSC-certified fish

title: Fish Conservation
description:
Efforts to protect fish populations and habitats.
Example: Coral reef protection

title: Endangered Fish Species
description:
Fish species at risk of extinction.
Example: Sturgeon

title: Invasive Fish Species
description:
Non-native fish species affecting ecosystems.
Example: Lionfish

title: Fish Diseases
description:
Diseases affecting fish health.
Example: Koi herpesvirus

title: Ichthyophthirius multifiliis
description:
A common fish disease caused by protozoan parasites.
Example: Ich disease

title: Fish Parasites
description:
Organisms that live on or inside fish causing harm.
Example: Leeches on fish

title: Gill Flukes
description:
Parasitic worms that infest fish gills.
Example: Fluke-infected fish

title: Anchor Worms
description:
Crustacean parasites attaching to fish skin.
Example: Carp anchor worms

title: Fish Immune System
description:
The defense system protecting fish from infections.
Example: Trout immune response

title: Fish Antibodies
description:
Proteins that help fish fight infections.
Example: Carp immunity

title: Stress in Fish
description:
Physiological responses in fish due to environmental factors.
Example: Overcrowding stress

title: Fish Hormones
description:
Chemical messengers regulating fish bodily functions.
Example: Growth hormone

title: Cortisol in Fish
description:
A stress hormone in fish.
Example: Salmon cortisol

title: Fish Toxicology
description:
The study of pollutants affecting fish health.
Example: Pesticide impact

title: Bioaccumulation
description:
The accumulation of toxins in fish tissues over time.
Example: Mercury in fish

title: Biomagnification
description:
The increase of toxin concentration through the food chain.
Example: Tuna mercury levels

title: Heavy Metal Pollution
description:
Harmful metal contaminants affecting fish health.
Example: Lead pollution

title: Microplastic Contamination
description:
The presence of plastic particles in fish ecosystems.
Example: Plastic ingestion
